capabilities.name: echo
capabilities.description:
Simple echo tool for testing that returns your message with 'Hello' prefix.

    WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
    - When testing if the MCP server is responsive
    - When verifying tool invocation is working correctly
    - For basic connectivity tests
    - When learning how to use the MCP server

    PARAMETER USAGE:
    - message: Any text string you want echoed back

    EXAMPLES:
    - message = 'world' returns 'Hello world'
    - message = 'testing' returns 'Hello testing'
    
    This is primarily a diagnostic tool to verify the system is working properly.

capabilities.name: search-code
capabilities.description:
Searches code across repositories using Sourcegraph's API. 
   
    Query parameters and syntax examples:
    
    - File search (default):
      - Basic search: functionName - Search for the term across repositories
      - Repository filter: repo:^github\.com/owner/repo$ - Limit search to specific repositories
      - File filter: file:\.js$ - Search only in files with specific patterns
      - Language filter: lang:javascript - Search only in specific language files
      - Combined filters: repo:^github\.com/org/repo$ file:\.js$ functionName
      - Content search: content:"exact phrase" - Search for exact text match
      - Boolean operators: term1 AND term2, term1 OR term2, term1 NOT term2
      - Regular expressions: /pattern/ or use patternType:regexp in query
      
    - Commit search:
      - Basic: type:commit searchTerm - Search in commit metadata
      - Message filter: type:commit message:"fix bug" - Search in commit messages
      - Author filter: type:commit author:username - Filter by commit author
      - Time filters: type:commit after:"2 weeks ago" or before:"2023-01-01"
      - Repository branch: repo:owner/repo@branch type:commit term - Search in specific branch
      - Example: type:commit message:"security fix" author:john after:"1 month ago"
 
    - Diff search:
      - Basic: type:diff searchTerm - Search in code changes
      - Added/removed code: type:diff select:commit.diff.added term - Only in added code
      - Repository filter: repo:owner/repo type:diff term - Limit to specific repositories
      - Time range: type:diff after:"1 week ago" term - Recent changes only
      - Example: type:diff select:commit.diff.removed securityCheck
      
    Notes:
    - The function automatically adds the appropriate type: parameter if not included in the query.
    - Results are limited to 20 by default. Use count:N in your query to adjust this limit.
    - For regex searches, use /pattern/ syntax or add patternType:regexp to your query.
    - All searches use keyword pattern matching by default (case-insensitive).

capabilities.name: search-commits
capabilities.description:
Search for commits in Sourcegraph repositories with flexible filtering options.

    WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
    - When you need to find specific commits across repositories
    - When searching for code changes by a particular author
    - When looking for commits within a particular timeframe
    - When searching for specific commit messages or fixes

    PARAMETER USAGE:
    - author: The username of the commit author (e.g., 'jane', 'john.doe')
    - message: Text to search for in commit messages (e.g., 'fix authentication bug')
    - after: Date filter in YYYY-MM-DD format (e.g., '2023-01-15') or relative time ('2 weeks ago')

    SEARCH EXAMPLES:
    - Find security fixes: message = 'security fix'
    - Find recent commits by a specific author: author = 'username', after = '2023-10-01'
    - Find all commits mentioning a specific feature: message = 'user authentication'
    
    Notes:
    - The tool automatically adds 'type:commit' to your search
    - Results are limited to 20 by default
    - Date strings in 'after' can be exact dates or relative like '2 weeks ago'
    - Commit results include hash, message, author, and date

capabilities.name: search-diffs
capabilities.description:
Search for code changes (diffs) in Sourcegraph repositories with detailed filtering.

    WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
    - When looking for specific code changes or modifications
    - When you need to find added or removed code
    - When tracking changes by specific authors
    - When investigating changes made during a particular time period

    PARAMETER USAGE:
    - query: Terms to search for in the changed code (e.g., 'fix memory leak')
    - author: Filter diffs by the commit author (e.g., 'jane.smith')
    - after: Filter for changes after a specific date (YYYY-MM-DD or relative time)

    ADVANCED SEARCH TECHNIQUES:
    - Find added code: query = 'select:commit.diff.added new_function'
    - Find removed code: query = 'select:commit.diff.removed old_function'
    - Limit to specific file types: query = 'path:\.js$ authentication'
    - Combine author with timeframe: author = 'alex', after = '2 months ago'
    
    Notes:
    - Diffs show hunks of changed code for each modification
    - Changes include file path, line number ranges, and exact modifications
    - The tool automatically adds 'type:diff' to your search
    - Results include commit context (message, author, date) along with the changes

capabilities.name: search-github-repos
capabilities.description:
Search for code, commits, or diffs specifically in GitHub repositories.

    WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
    - When you need to search within specific known GitHub repositories
    - When searching across multiple GitHub repos simultaneously
    - When you need targeted searches in open source projects
    - When you want to limit searches to verified repositories

    PARAMETER USAGE:
    - query: What to search for (e.g., 'render function', 'authentication middleware')
    - repos: Comma-separated list of GitHub repositories in 'owner/repo' format
    - type: The type of search to perform ('file', 'commit', or 'diff')

    REPOSITORY SPECIFICATION:
    - Single repository: 'microsoft/typescript'
    - Multiple repositories: 'facebook/react,angular/angular,vuejs/vue'
    - Organization-wide: Use multiple specific repos instead of wildcards
    
    EXAMPLES:
    - Find authentication code in React: query='authentication', repos='facebook/react'
    - Find GraphQL usage across popular frameworks: query='graphql', repos='apollographql/apollo-client,graphql/graphql-js'
    - Find recent security fixes: query='security fix', repos='kubernetes/kubernetes', type='commit'
    
    Notes:
    - Format repositories exactly as they appear on GitHub (owner/repo)
    - Searches within specified repos only, not forks or related projects
    - Can be combined with any syntax from search-code, search-commits, and search-diffs

capabilities.name: get-hover-documentation
capabilities.description:
Get hover documentation and type information for a symbol.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to see the documentation for a specific function, variable, or class
- When you want to check the type information for a variable or expression
- When you need quick information about a symbol without navigating to its definition
- When exploring unfamiliar code to understand how components work

PARAMETER USAGE:
- repository: The full repository name (e.g., 'github.com/owner/repo')
- path: The file path where the symbol appears (e.g., 'src/main.js')
- line: The zero-indexed line number where the symbol appears
- character: The zero-indexed character position of the symbol on that line

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Requires LSIF data to be available in Sourcegraph (precise code intelligence)
- For accurate results, the repository must be properly indexed in Sourcegraph
- Line and character positions are zero-indexed (unlike editors which often use 1-indexed)

EXAMPLES:
- Get information about a function: { repository: 'github.com/golang/go', path: 'src/net/http/server.go', line: 142, character: 15 }
- Check a variable's type: { repository: 'github.com/microsoft/typescript', path: 'src/compiler/program.ts', line: 124, character: 30 }

The results will show the documentation and type information for the symbol at the specified position.

capabilities.name: get-document-symbols
capabilities.description:
Get all symbols (functions, classes, variables, etc.) in a file.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to see a structural overview of a file
- When looking for specific functions or classes in a large file
- When analyzing the organization and hierarchy of code in a file
- When you want to quickly understand the contents of a file without reading all the code

PARAMETER USAGE:
- repository: The full repository name (e.g., 'github.com/owner/repo')
- path: The file path to analyze (e.g., 'src/main.js')

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Requires LSIF data to be available in Sourcegraph (precise code intelligence)
- For accurate results, the repository must be properly indexed in Sourcegraph
- Symbol kinds vary by language (e.g., classes, methods, functions, variables)
- Symbols will be organized hierarchically when possible (e.g., methods inside classes)

EXAMPLES:
- Get symbols in a JavaScript file: { repository: 'github.com/facebook/react', path: 'packages/react/src/React.js' }
- Analyze a complex TypeScript file: { repository: 'github.com/microsoft/vscode', path: 'src/vs/editor/editor.api.ts' }

The results will show all symbols in the file, their types, and their locations, organized hierarchically when possible.

capabilities.name: get-file-content
capabilities.description:
Get the raw content of a file from any repository.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to retrieve the contents of a specific file
- When analyzing a file's implementation details
- When you want to understand configuration files or scripts
- When you need to see how a specific file is structured

PARAMETER USAGE:
- repository: The full repository name (e.g., 'github.com/owner/repo')
- path: The file path within the repository (e.g., 'src/main.js')
- revision: Optional git revision/branch/tag (e.g., 'main', 'v1.0.0', or a commit SHA)

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Binary files will not display their content properly
- Very large files may be truncated
- For privacy and security, access is limited to repositories you have permissions for

EXAMPLES:
- Get a specific file: { repository: 'github.com/golang/go', path: 'src/net/http/server.go' }
- Get a file from a specific branch: { repository: 'github.com/facebook/react', path: 'packages/react/src/React.js', revision: 'experimental' }

The results will show the file's content with syntax highlighting for the appropriate language.

capabilities.name: get-file-blame
capabilities.description:
Get git blame information for a file.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to see who last modified a specific section of a file
- When investigating when and why a particular change was made
- When tracking the history and ownership of code
- When you want to understand how a file evolved over time

PARAMETER USAGE:
- repository: The full repository name (e.g., 'github.com/owner/repo')
- path: The file path within the repository (e.g., 'src/main.js')
- startLine: Optional zero-indexed start line for partial file blame (default: 0)
- endLine: Optional zero-indexed end line for partial file blame (default: 100)

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Line numbers are zero-indexed (unlike editors which often use 1-indexed)
- For large files, consider specifying a line range to improve performance
- The maximum recommended line range is 200 lines

EXAMPLES:
- Get blame for a specific file section: { repository: 'github.com/golang/go', path: 'src/net/http/server.go', startLine: 100, endLine: 150 }
- Get blame for the beginning of a file: { repository: 'github.com/facebook/react', path: 'packages/react/src/React.js' }

The results will show line ranges, authors, dates, and commit messages for each section of the file.

capabilities.name: lookup-cve
capabilities.description:
Search for CVEs affecting repositories or packages.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to check if a specific CVE affects a repository
- When you want to find vulnerabilities related to a specific package
- When investigating security issues in a codebase
- When performing security audits for packages or repositories

PARAMETER USAGE:
- cveId: Optional specific CVE ID to look up (e.g., 'CVE-2023-1234')
- package: Optional package name to check for vulnerabilities (e.g., 'lodash')
- repository: Optional repository name to check for vulnerabilities (e.g., 'github.com/owner/repo')

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- At least one parameter must be provided (cveId, package, or repository)
- Results include severity levels, affected versions, and remediation guidance when available
- Enterprise features may provide more detailed results

EXAMPLES:
- Look up a specific CVE: { cveId: 'CVE-2023-1234' }
- Check vulnerabilities for a package: { package: 'lodash' }
- Check vulnerabilities in a repository: { repository: 'github.com/facebook/react' }

The results will show detailed information about matching vulnerabilities including severity, affected versions, and available fixes.

capabilities.name: lookup-package-vulnerability
capabilities.description:
Check if specific packages have known vulnerabilities.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to check if a package has known security vulnerabilities
- When you want to audit a specific package version for security issues
- When investigating dependency security before adding to a project
- When checking if a package needs updating for security reasons

PARAMETER USAGE:
- package: The package name to check (e.g., 'lodash', 'react', 'django')
- version: Optional specific package version to check (e.g., '4.17.20')

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Without a version, all vulnerabilities for any version will be returned
- Results include severity levels, affected versions, and remediation guidance
- Different ecosystems (npm, PyPI, etc.) are supported

EXAMPLES:
- Check all vulnerabilities for a package: { package: 'lodash' }
- Check vulnerabilities for a specific version: { package: 'react', version: '16.8.0' }

The results will show detailed information about matching vulnerabilities including severity, affected versions, and available fixes.

capabilities.name: search-exploits
capabilities.description:
Search for exploit code for known vulnerabilities.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to assess the risk of a CVE by finding available exploits
- When researching how a vulnerability works
- When checking if a vulnerability has public proof-of-concept code
- When investigating security incidents related to specific CVEs

PARAMETER USAGE:
- cveId: The CVE ID to search for exploits (e.g., 'CVE-2023-1234')

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Results may include proof-of-concept code, exploits, or security research
- This tool searches across all indexed repositories
- For security research purposes only

EXAMPLES:
- Find exploits for a CVE: { cveId: 'CVE-2023-1234' }
- Research a well-known vulnerability: { cveId: 'CVE-2021-44228' } (Log4Shell)

The results will show code references that mention or implement exploits for the specified CVE.

capabilities.name: find-vendor-advisory
capabilities.description:
Find vendor security advisories.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to find official security advisories from vendors
- When researching how vendors have addressed specific security issues
- When looking for remediation guidance for security vulnerabilities
- When investigating security patches for specific products

PARAMETER USAGE:
- vendor: The vendor name (e.g., 'Microsoft', 'Apache', 'Oracle')
- product: The product name (e.g., 'Windows', 'Log4j', 'MySQL')

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Results include security advisories, bulletins, and announcements
- More specific vendor and product names yield better results
- Results are sourced from repositories that may contain security advisories

EXAMPLES:
- Find Microsoft Exchange advisories: { vendor: 'Microsoft', product: 'Exchange' }
- Find Apache Log4j advisories: { vendor: 'Apache', product: 'Log4j' }

The results will show security advisories, bulletins, and announcements from the specified vendor about the product.

capabilities.name: debug
capabilities.description:
Lists all available tools and methods in the MCP server. Use this to discover capabilities.

    WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
    - When you need to see what tools are available in the server
    - When you want to check which methods are supported
    - When debugging or exploring the MCP server capabilities
    - When you're unsure what functionality is available

    The output includes:
    - All registered tools with their names
    - Available resources like URLs
    - Registered prompts
    - Supported MCP methods
    
    No parameters are required. Simply call the tool to get a complete listing.

capabilities.description:
Conduct deep research on code patterns and architecture across repositories with advanced analysis capabilities.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need comprehensive understanding of complex codebases
- When searching for patterns across multiple repositories

capabilities.name: get-definition
capabilities.description:
Find the definition of a symbol in code.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to find where a function, variable, class, or other symbol is defined
- When you want to understand the origin and implementation of a specific code element
- When navigating unfamiliar code to understand its structure
- When verifying the actual implementation matches documentation

PARAMETER USAGE:
- repository: The full repository name (e.g., 'github.com/owner/repo')
- path: The file path where the symbol is being used (e.g., 'src/main.js')
- line: The zero-indexed line number where the symbol appears
- character: The zero-indexed character position of the symbol on that line

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Requires LSIF data to be available in Sourcegraph (precise code intelligence)
- For accurate results, the repository must be properly indexed in Sourcegraph
- Line and character positions are zero-indexed (unlike editors which often use 1-indexed)

EXAMPLES:
- Find where a function is defined: { repository: 'github.com/golang/go', path: 'src/net/http/server.go', line: 142, character: 15 }
- Look up a class definition: { repository: 'github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint', path: 'packages/eslint-plugin/src/rules/indent.ts', line: 24, character: 10 }

The results will show the location of the definition, and may include documentation/type information if available.

capabilities.name: find-references
capabilities.description:
Find all references to a symbol across repositories.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to find all places where a function, variable, or class is used
- When analyzing the impact of potential code changes or refactoring
- When understanding dependencies and usage patterns in a codebase
- When tracing execution paths through a complex system
- When determining if a piece of code is still in use before removing it

PARAMETER USAGE:
- repository: The full repository name (e.g., 'github.com/owner/repo')
- path: The file path where the symbol is defined or used (e.g., 'src/main.js')
- line: The zero-indexed line number where the symbol appears
- character: The zero-indexed character position of the symbol on that line
- limit: Maximum number of references to return (default: 50)

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Requires LSIF data to be available in Sourcegraph (precise code intelligence)
- For accurate results, the repository must be properly indexed in Sourcegraph
- Cross-repository references require proper indexing of all relevant repositories
- Line and character positions are zero-indexed (unlike editors which often use 1-indexed)

EXAMPLES:
- Find references to a function: { repository: 'github.com/golang/go', path: 'src/net/http/server.go', line: 142, character: 15, limit: 100 }
- Analyze usage of a class: { repository: 'github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint', path: 'packages/eslint-plugin/src/rules/indent.ts', line: 24, character: 10 }

The results will show all files and locations where the symbol is referenced, organized by repository and file.

capabilities.name: find-implementations
capabilities.description:
Find implementations of interfaces, classes, or methods across repositories.

WHEN TO USE THIS TOOL:
- When you need to find all concrete implementations of an interface or abstract class
- When exploring how different components implement a common contract
- When understanding the variety of implementations for a specific method
- When analyzing polymorphic behavior across a codebase
- When evaluating the impact of interface changes on implementing classes

PARAMETER USAGE:
- repository: The full repository name (e.g., 'github.com/owner/repo')
- path: The file path where the interface or abstract class is defined (e.g., 'src/interfaces.ts')
- line: The zero-indexed line number where the interface appears
- character: The zero-indexed character position of the interface on that line
- limit: Maximum number of implementations to return (default: 50)

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Requires LSIF data to be available in Sourcegraph (precise code intelligence)
- This feature is most effective in strongly-typed languages (Java, C#, TypeScript, Go, etc.)
- For accurate results, the repository must be properly indexed in Sourcegraph
- Cross-repository implementations require proper indexing of all relevant repositories
- Line and character positions are zero-indexed (unlike editors which often use 1-indexed)

EXAMPLES:
- Find implementations of an interface: { repository: 'github.com/golang/go', path: 'src/io/io.go', line: 78, character: 6, limit: 100 }
- Discover classes implementing an interface: { repository: 'github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework', path: 'spring-core/src/main/java/org/springframework/core/io/Resource.java', line: 24, character: 17 }

The results will show all files and locations where the interface or abstract class is implemented, organized by repository and file.
